definition: A digital ledger of transactions that is duplicated and distributed across the entire network of computer systems on the blockchain.
A digital or virtual currency that is secured by cryptography, making it nearly impossible to counterfeit or double-spend.
The first and most widely recognized cryptocurrency, created in 2009 by an unknown person or group using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto.
Any cryptocurrency other than Bitcoin.
The process of validating transactions and adding them to the blockchain ledger, often rewarded with new coins.
A digital tool that allows users to store and manage their cryptocurrencies.
Self-executing contracts with the terms directly written into code, automatically enforcing and executing agreements.
Decentralized Finance; financial services built on blockchain technology that operate without centralized intermediaries.
Non-Fungible Token; a unique digital asset that represents ownership of a specific item or piece of content.
The process of actively participating in transaction validation on a proof-of-stake blockchain, often by locking up coins.
Initial Coin Offering; a fundraising method where new projects sell their cryptocurrency tokens to early investors.
A distribution of a cryptocurrency token or coin, usually for free, to numerous wallet addresses.
A term derived from a misspelling of 'hold' that refers to the strategy of buying and holding cryptocurrency regardless of price fluctuations.
A fee required to perform a transaction or execute a contract on the Ethereum blockchain network.
The economics of a token or cryptocurrency, including its creation, distribution, and management.
The practice of staking or lending crypto assets to generate high returns or rewards in the form of additional cryptocurrency.
A collection of funds locked in a smart contract, used to facilitate decentralized trading, lending, and other functions.
Decentralized Autonomous Organization; an organization represented by rules encoded as a computer program that is transparent and controlled by the organization members.
A secondary framework or protocol built on top of an existing blockchain to improve its scalability and efficiency.
Government-issued currency that is not backed by a physical commodity, such as gold or silver.
